what: What problem does TaxSEA actually solve?
title: Frequently Asked Questions
text: Traditional differential abundance looks individual microbes change. TaxSEA looks groups microbes shared biology change together. shift matters human microbiomes highly individual — chasing single species noisy rarely reproducible. TaxSEA helps detect biology ’s consistent across people.

what: Is TaxSEA a replacement for differential abundance?
title: Frequently Asked Questions
text: , ’s complement, replacement. practice, DA often tells look. TaxSEA helps understand means.

what: Can I use TaxSEA even when there are no individual species level differences?
title: Frequently Asked Questions
text: , ’s complement, replacement. practice, DA often tells look. TaxSEA helps understand means.

what: How is this different from functional profiling tools like HUMAnN3?
title: Frequently Asked Questions
text: answer different questions. - HUMAnN3 → genes pathways present? - TaxSEA → known biological traits signatures shifting taxon level? Sometimes overlap. Sometimes don’t don’t always good gene annotations. TaxSEA especially useful traits known biologically well captured gene annotations.

what: Does this only work for the human gut microbiome?
title: Frequently Asked Questions
text: ’s works best right now, curated databases focus . However since introduced BacDive database utility non-human microbiomes. framework general : - taxa - ranks (logFC, correlations, etc.) - meaningful trait groupings can use TaxSEA systems .

what: Do I need differential abundance results first?
title: Frequently Asked Questions
text: necessarily.TaxSEA just needs ranked list taxa: - log2 fold changes - correlations phenotype - effect sizes statistical model

what: Why use ranks instead of thresholds?
title: Frequently Asked Questions
text: taxon set enrichment approaches exist, however use threshold define taxa interest However, thresholds throw away information. microbiome data especially, signals weak noisy, arbitrary cut-offs often decide biology. example, 10 short chain fatty acid producers decreased false discovery rate 0.06 probably interesting biology powered detect individual taxa. Rank-based enrichment keeps taxa play asks whether meaningful groups drift together.

what: Isn’t this just gene set enrichment, but for microbes?
title: Frequently Asked Questions
text: Yes, ’s point. Genomics moved past single-gene thinking years ago. Microbiome analysis just catching . TaxSEA brings logic set-level biology microbial communities.

what: Will this work if my DA results are messy or inconsistent?
title: Frequently Asked Questions
text: ’s exactly TaxSEA useful. different DA methods give different taxa kinds microbes keep appearing (e.g. oxygen-tolerant, SCFA producers, disease-associated), TaxSEA surface shared signal.

what: Have you shown TaxSEA is accurate?
title: Frequently Asked Questions
text: Yes, provided rigorous evaluation accuracy original publication Pham et al. 2025 black boxes, heavy modelling assumptions. Just clean question: biologically related microbes shifting together expected chance?

what: When should I not use TaxSEA?
title: Frequently Asked Questions
text: TaxSEA fast cheap run, practice ’s almost always worth trying. said, situations ’s best tool. TaxSEA tends work less well : - Diversity low. example early-life microbiomes (e.g. infants), simply taxa meaningful set-level patterns emerge. system highly controlled. n pre-clinical models microbiomes much consistent individuals (mice example coprophagic communities homogenise). settings, classic differential abundance often works better. hypothesis single organism. ’re essentially studying something closer infection model, DA right tool. TaxSEA really shines data heterogeneous (e.g. adult human gut microbiomes), signals subtle. example overall diversity shifts, single taxon stands “significant”.

what: Can I use TaxSEA with 16S rRNA gene sequencing data?
title: Frequently Asked Questions
text: Technically, yes works best shotgun metagenomic data. TaxSEA designed around species- strain-level resolution. 16S data ’re usually limited higher taxonomic ranks, means lose lot biological resolution, many meaningful traits (e.g. metabolite production) can’t assigned confidently. said, ’ve included genus-level taxon sets database, TaxSEA still run can useful high-level patterns. Just aware results coarser generally less powerful using shotgun metagenomics.

what: Why does TaxSEA use species-level data instead of strain-level?
title: Frequently Asked Questions
text: deliberately work species level bring consistency heterogeneous human microbiome data. Strain-level profiles even variable across people species. practice, makes enrichment-style analyses noisy, slow, hard reproduce. make trade-: lose fine-grained detail, gain stability, speed, interpretability. ’s also practical reason. many traits TaxSEA uses, underlying evidence either conserved species level (e.g. oxygen tolerance, broad metabolic capacity, prior disease associations), comes experiments one type strains. even wanted work fully strain resolution, biological annotation often isn’t . Yes, means may miss strain-specific effects individual samples. population-scale human microbiome studies, species-level analysis strikes better balance biological meaning practical usability.

title: TaxSEA
text: TaxSEA R package designed enable rapid interpretation differential abundance analysis correlation analysis output microbiota data. TaxSEA takes input vector genus species names rank. example log2 fold changes, Spearman’s rho. TaxSEA uses Kolmogorov-Smirnov test identify particular group species genera (.e. set taxa butyrate producers) skewed one end distribution . Simply put, TaxSEA allows users rapidly go list species metabolite producers altered, findings similar previously published study.

title: TaxSEA
text: install latest version TaxSEA Bioconductor:
code: if (!requireNamespace("BiocManager", quietly = TRUE))     install.packages("BiocManager")  BiocManager::install("TaxSEA")

title: TaxSEA
text: TaxSEA utilizes taxon sets generated five reference databases (gutMGene, GMrepo v2, MiMeDB, mBodyMap, BugSigDB). Please cite appropriate database using: Cheng et al. gutMGene: comprehensive database target genes gut microbes microbial metabolites Nucleic Acids Res. 2022. Dai et al. GMrepo v2: curated human gut microbiome database special focus disease markers cross-dataset comparison Nucleic Acids Res. 2022. Wishart et. al. MiMeDB: Human Microbial Metabolome Database Nucleic Acids Res. 2023. Jin et al. mBodyMap: curated database microbes across human body associations health diseases. Nucleic Acids Res. 2022. Geistlinger et al. BugSigDB captures patterns differential abundance across broad range host-associated microbial signatures. Nature Biotech. 2023.

title: TaxSEA
text: test data provided TaxSEA consists log2 fold changes comparing healthy IBD. count data downloaded curatedMetagenomeData fold changes generated LinDA. Hall et al. novel Ruminococcus gnavus clade enriched inflammatory bowel disease patients Genome Med. 2017 Nov 28;9(1):103. Pasolli et al. Accessible, curated metagenomic data ExperimentHub. Nat Methods. 2017 Oct 31;14(11):1023-1024. doi: 10.1038/nmeth.4468. Zhou et al. LinDA: linear models differential abundance analysis microbiome compositional data. Genome Biol. 2022 Apr 14;23(1):95.

title: TaxSEA
text: get_taxon_sets(taxon): Retrieves taxon sets contain particular taxon list taxon names. get_ncbi_taxon_ids(taxon_names): Retrieves NCBI Taxonomy IDs list taxon names. TaxSEA(taxon_ranks, database = ""): Taxon set enrichment analysis.

text: required TaxSEA named vector log2 fold changes groups species genera. TaxSEA work ranks higher species genus. input taxa tested, limited pre-defined set (e.g. use threshold significance remove taxa). See example format. TaxSEA lookup convert taxon names NCBI taxonomic identifiers. TaxSEA stores commonly observed identifiers internally save time. TaxSEA can also utilise custom databases named list taxon sets. case ID conversion disabled expected input names database names format Input IDs format like one following - Species name. E.g. “Bifidobacterium longum”, “Bifidobacterium_longum” - Genus name. E.g. “Bifidobacterium” - NCBI ID E.g. 216816

E.g. x <- paste0(   "d__Bacteria.p__Actinobacteriota.c__Actinomycetes.",   "o__Bifidobacteriales.f__Bifidobacteriaceae.g__Bifidobacterium") x = strsplit(x,split="\\.")[[1]][6] x = gsub("g__","",x) print(x) ## [1] "Bifidobacterium" ## Example test data library(TaxSEA) data(TaxSEA_test_data) head(sample(TaxSEA_test_data),4) ##   Holdemania_filiformis  Clostridium_sp_CAG_242 Bifidobacterium_bifidum  ##                  -1.609                   0.275                   3.146  ##        Actinomyces_oris  ##                   1.336

what: The challenge with interpreting differences in microbiome data
title: Why use taxon set enrichment analysis?
text: human microbiome studies, common goal compare microbial profiles groups. example, treated vs untreated, disease vs control, timepoint 1 vs timepoint 2. usually differential abundance (DA) analysis, tests whether individual bacteria differ groups. many DA methods, share basic premise: test microbes one one. Although standard practice, raises problem rarely discussed. People rarely share exact microbial species. Even large cohorts, taxa low-prevalence. example, Human Microbiome Project, applying modest 20% prevalence filter (species must appear ≥20% samples) removes vast majority species analysis.  Figure 1. left, heatmap species-level profiles eight randomly selected participants Human Microbiome Project shows samples cluster almost perfectly individual, highlighting strong inter-individual variation. right, histogram common commensal species prevalence demonstrates many taxa absent samples, illustrating species-level differential abundance often sparse hard reproduce. time, still consensus “best” DA method. fact, method choice can dominate biology: across 53 real gut microbiome studies, several widely used DA tools produced inconsistent results. benchmark suggests much call DA signal often prevalence-driven (zeros vs non-zeros) rather subtle abundance shifts Pelto et al., 2025 Much field therefore focused finding optimal DA method. fundamental question rarely ask: differential abundance right question begin ? course, possible single microbe drives phenotype. one bacterium responsible complex diseases inflammatory bowel disease, likely identified long ago. Instead, observe overwhelming majority human microbiome studies dominance single species, coordinated shifts across whole communities, patterns often described terms diversity dysbiosis. problem concepts usually actionable. relative descriptions: single “dysbiotic” “healthy” microbiome, even diversity contextual measure rather biological mechanism O’Toole et al., 2023 Recent large-scale meta-analyses reinforce view, showing many -called dysbiotic signatures reflect shared, non-specific response disease limited diagnostic mechanistic value Duvallet et al., 2017 (Duvallet et al., 2017; O’Toole et al., 2023). ’omics fields, single-feature testing makes far sense. comparing gene expression, epigenomes, proteomes, samples broadly share set features, differ levels, whether features exist . microbiome data, assumption breaks completely: universally shared species. short: traditional differential abundance asks us compare microbes one one, human microbiomes don’t work way. species rare, poorly shared people, results depend heavily method choose. usually observe real studies single “causal” microbes, broad, coordinated shifts across communities: patterns DA struggles capture consistent biologically meaningful way.

what: The idea behind Taxon Set Enrichment Analysis
title: Why use taxon set enrichment analysis?
text: Taxon Set Enrichment Analysis starts simple observation: human microbiome studies, biology rarely driven single species. changes instead groups microbes share common trait. Rather asking “individual bugs changed?”, TSEA asks useful question: “microbes shared biological property shifting together?” example, seeing shifts : facultative anaerobes? taxa previously associated inflammatory bowel disease? butyrate producers? mucin-utilisers? TaxSEA implements idea R package using curated biological databases define thousands groups, applying rank-based enrichment test. hood, TaxSEA also handles lot practical complexity harmonising taxon names across databases, converting identifiers, providing consistently formatted resources different knowledge bases can used together.

what: But isn’t this what functional profiling tools (e.g. HUMAnN3) do?
title: Why use taxon set enrichment analysis?
text: really. Functional profiling tools work directly gene families pathways. TaxSEA works traits linked taxa (species/strains) based prior knowledge curated resources. approaches related, . example, may know species can utilise mucin vitro work, even precise genes pathways responsible unclear (inconsistently annotated). case, trait-based grouping can capture biology pathway-based methods might miss. Similarly, TaxSEA can tell whether data recapitulates microbial signature previously reported another disease context — something functional tools designed . TaxSEA also lightweight: needs species label plus rank (e.g. log2 fold change correlation) runs seconds laptop. meant replace functional profiling, complement — providing biological context prioritisation invest time resources deeper functional analyses.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Feargal Ryan. Author, maintainer, funder.            Supported NHMRC Investigator Grant

title: Authors and Citation
text: Pham C, Rankin T, Stinear T, Walsh C, Ryan F (2025). “TaxSEA: rapid interpretation microbiome alterations using taxon set enrichment analysis public databases.” Briefings Bioinformatics, Volume 26, Issue 2. doi:10.1093/bib/bbaf173, https://doi.org/10.1093/bib/bbaf173.
code: @Article{,   title = {TaxSEA: rapid interpretation of microbiome alterations using taxon set enrichment analysis and public databases},   author = {Cong M Pham and Timothy J Rankin and Timothy P Stinear and Calum J Walsh and Feargal J Ryan},   journal = {Briefings in Bioinformatics},   year = {2025},   volume = {Volume 26, Issue 2},   doi = {10.1093/bib/bbaf173},   url = {https://doi.org/10.1093/bib/bbaf173}, }

title: TaxSEA
text: Available BioconductorRead paper Briefings Bioinformatics

title: TaxSEA
text: Traditional differential abundance (DA) analysis looks individual microbes going . sounds sensible human microbiome studies often falls apart everyone’s microbiome unique, species shared across people. TaxSEA doesn’t test individual species rather group species shared characteristic different. example seeing shift bugs increased oxygen tolerance, increase bugs produce certain metabolite enzyme, even seeing change bugs known disease association humans. want know check paper, find approach far reproducible standard DA analysis well capable extracting biologically meaningful patterns. TaxSEA usually can run within seconds standard hardware. TaxSEA can also test differences particular taxonomic rank. example instead just summing species genus. see distribution species within genus different groups. powerful approach simply summing/aggregating rank can risk missing can get shifts within genus/family. short, TaxSEA makes easy intepret changes microbiome data. TaxSEA takes input vector genus species names rank. example log2 fold changes Spearman’s rho. TaxSEA uses Kolmogorov-Smirnov test identify particular group species genera (.e. set taxa butyrate producers) skewed one end distribution. Note: Although TaxSEA principle can applied microbiome data source, databases utilized largely cover human associated microbiomes human gut microbiome particular. TaxSEA likely perform best human gut microbiome data.

title: TaxSEA
text: default TaxSEA utilizes taxon sets generated six reference databases (BacDive,gutMGene, GMrepo v2, MiMeDB, mBodyMap, BugSigDB). See examples using custom databases taxonomically defined taxon sets. Please cite appropriate database using: Schober et al. BacDive 2025: core database prokaryotic strain data. Nucleic Acids Res. 2025. Cheng et al. gutMGene: comprehensive database target genes gut microbes microbial metabolites. Nucleic Acids Res. 2022. Dai et al. GMrepo v2: curated human gut microbiome database special focus disease markers cross-dataset comparison Nucleic Acids Res. 2022. Wishart et. al. MiMeDB: Human Microbial Metabolome Database Nucleic Acids Res. 2023. Jin et al. mBodyMap: curated database microbes across human body associations health diseases. Nucleic Acids Res. 2022. Geistlinger et al. BugSigDB captures patterns differential abundance across broad range host-associated microbial signatures. Nature Biotech. 2023.

title: TaxSEA
code: if (!requireNamespace("BiocManager", quietly = TRUE))     install.packages("BiocManager") BiocManager::install("TaxSEA")

title: TaxSEA
code: library(TaxSEA)  # Retrieve taxon sets containing Bifidobacterium longum. blong.sets <- get_taxon_sets(taxon="Bifidobacterium_longum")  # Run TaxSEA with test data provided data(TaxSEA_test_data) taxsea_results <- TaxSEA(taxon_ranks=TaxSEA_test_data)  #Enrichments among metabolite producers from gutMgene and MiMeDB metabolites.df <- taxsea_results$Metabolite_producers  #Enrichments among health and disease signatures from GMRepoV2 and mBodyMap disease.df <- taxsea_results$Health_associations  #Enrichments among published associations from BugSigDB bsdb.df <- taxsea_results$BugSigdB

title: TaxSEA
text: required TaxSEA vector R containing ranks (e.g. log2 fold changes) names (E.g. species/genus). TaxSEA work ranks higher species genus. input taxa tested, limited pre-defined set (e.g. use threshold significance remove taxa). See example format. TaxSEA lookup convert taxon names NCBI taxonomic identifiers. TaxSEA stores commonly observed identifiers internally look whatever covered save time. Input IDs format like one following Species name. E.g. “Bifidobacterium longum”, “Bifidobacterium_longum” Genus name. E.g. “Bifidobacterium” NCBI ID E.g. 216816
code: #Input IDs with the full taxonomic lineage should be split up. E.g. x <- "d__Bacteria.p__Actinobacteriota.c__Actinomycetes.o__Bifidobacteriales.f__Bifidobacteriaceae.g__Bifidobacterium" x <- strsplit(x,split="\\.")[[1]][6] x <- gsub("g__","",x)  ## Running this through a vector of IDs may look something like the following #new_ids <- sapply(as.character(old_ids),function(y) {strsplit(x = y,split="\\.")[[1]][6]}) #new_ids <- gsub("g__","",new_ids)  ## Example test data library(TaxSEA) data("TaxSEA_test_data") head(sample(TaxSEA_test_data),4)

title: TaxSEA
code: data("TaxSEA_test_data") taxsea_results <- TaxSEA(taxon_ranks=TaxSEA_test_data)  #Enrichments among metabolite producers from gutMgene and MiMeDB metabolites.df <- taxsea_results$Metabolite_producers  #Enrichments among health and disease signatures from GMRepoV2 and mBodyMap disease.df <- taxsea_results$Health_associations  #Enrichments among published associations from BugSigDB bsdb.df <- taxsea_results$BugSigDB

title: TaxSEA
text: output list three data frames providing enrichment results metabolite producers, health/disease associations, published signatures BugSigDB. dataframe 5 columns taxonSetName - name taxon set tested median_rank - simply median rank across detected members set. allows see direction change P value - Kolmogorov-Smirnov test P value. FDR - P value adjusted multiple testing. TaxonSet - Returns list taxa set show driving signal

title: TaxSEA
text: Many users may want utilise TaxSEA custom database. example testing flag TaxSEA function “custom_db” expects input named list vectors. format default TaxSEA database. Note: using custom_db flag disables automatic ID conversion NCBI API lookup. However functionality available via functions
code: # Perform enrichment analysis using TaxSEA custom_taxsea_results <- TaxSEA(taxon_ranks = log2_fold_changes, custom_db = custom_taxon_sets) custom_taxsea_results <- custom_taxsea_results$custom_sets

what: Testing for differences in taxonomically defined sets
title: TaxSEA
text: addition taxon sets defined function phenotype, users can define sets based taxonomy. Current methods test higher taxonomic levels (e.g., genus family), involve aggregating counts approach opposing shifts individual species may cancel , obscuring meaningful biological patterns. instance, antibiotic treatment may suppress certain species allowing resistant species within genus expand occupy vacant niche, creating ecological shift appears net change broader taxonomic levels. utilise data Chng et al. demonstrating comparison Atopic dermatitis controls.
code: #### Applying TaxSEA functionality to taxonomic ranks   # This script applies TaxSEA to identify taxonomic enrichment at different taxonomic levels. # Specifically, we analyze enrichment at the family level using metagenomic data  # Load required libraries library(TaxSEA) library(curatedMetagenomicData) library(tidyverse) library(phyloseq) library(MicrobiomeStat) library(dplyr)  # Load sample metadata metadata_all <- sampleMetadata  # Filter metadata for the specific study (ChngKR_2016) metadata <- metadata_all %>%    filter(study_name == "ChngKR_2016") %>%    column_to_rownames('sample_id')  # Extract count data using curatedMetagenomicData cmd_data <- curatedMetagenomicData(   pattern = "ChngKR_2016.relative_abundance",   counts = TRUE,   dryrun = FALSE )  # Convert the extracted data to a count matrix counts_data <- assay(cmd_data[[1]]) counts_data <- counts_data[, rownames(metadata)]  # Subset to relevant samples  # Filter taxa with at least one sample having counts > 100 counts_data <- counts_data[apply(counts_data > 100, 1, sum) > 0, ]  # Extract species names from taxonomic strings species_names <- gsub("s__", "", sapply(rownames(counts_data), function(y) strsplit(y, "\\|")[[1]][7])) rownames(counts_data) <- species_names  # Create a taxonomic lineage dataframe # Remove taxonomic prefixes (k__, p__, c__, etc.) and separate into taxonomic ranks  # make data frame of taxon lineages taxon_lineages <- data.frame(Name = species_names,                              Lineage = names(species_names)) %>%   mutate(Lineage = str_remove_all(Lineage, '[kpcofgs]__')) %>%   separate(col = Lineage, into = c('kingdom', 'phylum', 'class',                                     'order', 'family', 'genus', 'species'),             sep = '\\|') %>%   mutate(name = Name) %>%   remove_rownames() %>%   column_to_rownames('name')  # Perform differential abundance testing using LinDA metadata$study_condition <- factor(metadata$study_condition, levels = c("control", "AD"))  linda_results <- linda(   feature.dat = counts_data,   meta.dat = metadata,   formula = '~study_condition',   feature.dat.type = 'count',   prev.filter = 0.05 )  # Extract log2 fold change values for differential taxa linda_results <- linda_results$output$study_conditionAD log2_fold_changes <- linda_results$log2FoldChange names(log2_fold_changes) <- rownames(linda_results)  # Define the taxonomic rank for enrichment analysis selected_taxon_level <- 'genus'  # Modify as needed (e.g., genus, phylum)  # Create a named list of species grouped by taxonomic rank custom_taxon_sets <- taxon_lineages %>%   group_by(.data[[selected_taxon_level]]) %>%    summarise(species = list(species), .groups = "drop") %>%   deframe()  # Perform enrichment analysis using TaxSEA custom_taxsea_results <- TaxSEA(taxon_ranks = log2_fold_changes, custom_db = custom_taxon_sets) custom_taxsea_results <- custom_taxsea_results$custom_sets

title: TaxSEA
text: results generated using TaxSEA output differential abundance analysis comparing disease control. input per species log2 fold changes taxa Inflammatory Bowel disease control. TaxSEA identified significant depletion producers certain short chain fatty acids. Using barplots can show overall signatures identified significantly different. can highlight individual species contributing signature volcano plot.

title: TaxSEA
text: format BugSigDB publication entered “Study”, within different experiments signatures. example one signatures may taxa increased experiment, another signature taxa decreased. Users can find querying BugSigDB. recent updates BugSigDB moved using PubMed ID study ID (Although studies yet). See example.
code: library(bugsigdbr) #This package is installable via Bioconductor bsdb <- importBugSigDB() #Import database   #E.g. if the BugSigDB identifier you found enriched was bsdb:11/1/1 #This is Study 11, Experiment 1, Signature 1 bsdb[bsdb$Study=="Study 11" &       bsdb$Experiment=="Experiment 1" &       bsdb$Signature=="Signature 1",]

what: TaxSEA database with other enrichment tools
title: TaxSEA
text: TaxSEA function default uses Kolmogorov Smirnov test original idea inspired gene set enrichment analyses RNASeq. users wish use alternative gene set enrichment analysis tool database formatted way possible. See example fast gene set enrichment analysis (fgsea).
code: library(fgsea) #This package is installable via Bioconductor data(TaxSEA_DB) #Convert input names to NCBI taxon ids names(TaxSEA_test_data) = get_ncbi_taxon_ids(names(TaxSEA_test_data)) TaxSEA_test_data = TaxSEA_test_data[!is.na(names(TaxSEA_test_data))]  #Run fgsea fgsea_results <- fgsea(TaxSEA_db, TaxSEA_test_data, minSize=5, maxSize=500)

text: NCBI

what: TaxSEA: Taxon Set Enrichment Analysis — TaxSEA
title: TaxSEA: Taxon Set Enrichment Analysis — TaxSEA
text: TaxSEA enables rapid annotation changes testing enrichment pre-defined taxon sets.

title: TaxSEA: Taxon Set Enrichment Analysis — TaxSEA
code: TaxSEA(   taxon_ranks,   lookup_missing = FALSE,   min_set_size = 5,   max_set_size = 100,   custom_db = NULL )

title: TaxSEA: Taxon Set Enrichment Analysis — TaxSEA
text: taxon_ranks named vector log2 fold changes control test groups. lookup_missing Logical indicating whether fetch missing NCBI IDs. Default FALSE. min_set_size Minimum size taxon sets include analysis. Default 5. max_set_size Maximum size taxon sets include analysis. Default 100. custom_db user-provided list taxon sets. NULL (default), built-database used.

title: TaxSEA: Taxon Set Enrichment Analysis — TaxSEA
text: list data frames taxon set enrichment results.

title: TaxSEA: Taxon Set Enrichment Analysis — TaxSEA
